subtitle: Hello and welcome, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. I imagine that by now many of you already
realize that in conjunction with White Crow Books we've just launched the New
Thinking Allowed dialogues, book imprint, and our first title is, Is There Life
After Death?
Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery
with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome, I'm Emmy Vadnais, co-host with Jeffrey Mishlove.
Our topic today is harnessing the power of dream incubation.
My guest is Machiel Klerk, who is a mental health therapist, dream worker,
and an initiated shamanic diviner. He is the founder of a young platform,
which is an organization that provides programs for personal development
from a soul-centered perspective. He travels to Africa, throughout Europe and
United States, lecturing on soul-oriented psychological topics.
Machiel is author of Dream Guidance, connecting
to the soul through dream incubation.
He is located in Mexico City, now I'll switch over to the internet video.
Welcome, Machiel It is such a joy to be with you today.
Thank you, Emmy. I've been looking forward to this, and so glad to be here.
You have been traveling around the world, exploring dream incubation and dream work.
You've even gone to Greece and slept in temples, where you can connect with
Asclepius, who can help people with their dreams. And for you, it seems that this all
started when you lost your father at a young age.
Yeah, that is true. In a certain way, the death of my father when I was ten
opened up to the other world, the world behind the world.
And that world behind the world is, at one way, the world of dream.
But also what Carl Jung would call the collective unconscious.
And he said another word in term for the
collective unconscious is the length of the death.
And so the death moved from this reality into the other world.
And at the age of ten, there was a massive heartbreak and disconnect.
I didn't know about my father being in the other world. It was just disappeared.
And for a long time, that was a dark cloud around my life.
And in my early 20s, I started studying dreams and the dream world opened up.
And I reconnected with my father. There was deeply healing.
And I learned about healing and guiding potential that's in dreams.
So, yeah, that terrible event.
Another way was also the place that provided deep blessing.
So what got you hooked on exploring dreams even further?
Well, mainly that I had been living with this
unbelievable heartbreak that I just covered up.
And that generated in a sense of depression, I was in a dark pit.
And dreams provided the lifeline out of the pit to a life
that reconnected me to a sense of purpose, a sense of meaning.
And also provided the different world view.
If you really study dreams, you start noticing that there are some things
like synchronicity and other states of consciousness and something supportive.
And by being connected to that, I felt so grateful and life became so much
better that I never let go of that lifeline again and stayed connected.
And sure, life goes up and down and it's not that pain and suffering disappears.
But at least there's purpose and meaning to the whole enterprise of being on earth.
Yeah. Did your father spontaneously come to you in dreams? Or did you seek him out?
No, in the beginning it was spontaneous.
Because I didn't even really know that I hoped somehow there was a world
after death, but I didn't even know that from a personal experience.
And then so he showed up in dreams and it felt like he was really visiting me.
And these dreams, I woke up from them with such a sense of
being with him and a sense of healing that came from him.
That made me wonder about is he living on and then I met other deceased
relatives that also seemed to be autonomous and have messages for me.
And it was of course a very turbulent phase because
from a somewhat limited world view, my world just
expanded significantly to, hey, there's a world coexisting
to this world where the deceased seemed to live on.
And they're in the here right now and we can still communicate with
them, not like you go to dinner with them, but they're still around.
And what it also brought is if there's life after death, what might be
the goal of life, what will happen at death and what is important for me
to do right now so that I arrive at the door of death in a way that I
will be satisfied both looking back as with my ability to move forward.
And since then I imagine you supported others to connect
with their deceased loved ones or ancestors through dreams.
Yes, and what it mainly is for people is just turn towards your dream.
Your dreams are interested in helping and educating.
They're trying to realize your own potential.
Just like the rose seed wants to become a rose and the acorn and oak.
The human being wants to become a human
being and the dreams or the soul communicates
through this imaginal world about one's own potential, one's own wounds, one's gifts.
And by just paying attention to that,
something really miraculous starts happening.
So when people lose a lot of one, just start paying attention and doesn't
mean that the first, second or third night the loved ones shows up.
But if you give it several months and you're kind of
giving it the benefit of the doubt, you will start
getting a lot of interesting information and
experiences that people usually find very beneficial.
And reading your book, it seems that having a
relationship with a dream, inviting it forward,
having an intention, perhaps even a question
can allow these types of experiences to occur.
Yes, the old idea, ask, and you shall be given, comes
back in almost any culture and any spiritual tradition.
And it also applies to the world of dream and its inhabitants.
We can proactively reach out to the dream with any problem that's relevant to our
life and ask for support or guidance or more insight in the challenge that we face.
And then it's almost like we visit the most
interesting and smartest, wisest, counsellor,
therapist that is possible, the own deep self
or the divine or whatever you want to call it.
And it will support us and give us some guidance.
And so we don't need to just wait for the dream to come to us.
If we turn to it and say, hey, I'm in trouble or I would like
to learn more about this or can I be a more loving person.
There's something in our own psyche or in our own soul that is
rejoiced by us reaching out and based on standby and wants to help us.
And that's what I describe how to do that in my book.
It seems that it's a profound way of also
accessing one's own inner knowing or intuition.
Yes. And I've worked a lot with African shamans because I was born in South Africa.
So my dreams brought me back to Africa and I connected with the indigenous healers.
And some of them told me that the word intuition didn't exist in their language.
They called it connecting with ancestor.
And ancestor will be a broad term for anyone that's in the other world, deceased
or never been in this world or spirit guides or whatever beings that are there.
And they are just telling us these things that we here
in the West translate as, oh, I have an intuition.
And they say, well, it's actually your spirit
guide or your ancestor just helping you.
Right. And some might say it's your guardian angel.
Yes.
Our past loved one.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Can you take us to your experience of going to one of the temples in Greece
and really essentially going on a
pilgrimage of connecting with a long lineage
of those who would go to these temples to connect with a sleepiest,
to gain insight into their lives, perhaps receive even healing.
Yes. So there's this, what you're referring to is a very old tradition.
And even one of the earliest writings is about people
proactively asking the dream and its inhabitants for support.
And the best way that comes back in all these
cultures is to go on a certain pilgrimage.
And the pilgrimage is both an external journey to an
sacred place as an internal preparation for the night
that we connect with the spirit guide or God or the
divine or the mystery or something larger than ourselves.
And so I also went to Greece.
And I mimicked this process.
And I would walk to one of these temples and have the
experience of walking there in a tradition that existed
for over a thousand years where people would come
from all over the country with a question to the God
as clapias for very often physical healing.
And sometimes spiritual questions or practical things as I
lost my son in the war or he didn't return what happened.
So a broader range with the majority where physical was physical healing.
And then I would walk in those footsteps of all these thousands and
thousands of people who had somehow figured out that you can connect
with the healing forces, the creative forces through dreaming, but
especially by building up a whole ritual, a pilgrimage around it.
So it's not just, hey dream, I have this
problem, help me or I have a pain here, heal me.
It is a real building up of a relationship to as
clapias or the healing spirit and a preparation.
And I've studied it a lot and I thought what it really does,
it pumps up one's own intention, expectation, focus, one's
belief, and then being in community where other people have had
a healing experience will reinforce his sense of this works.
So the more I believe it works, the more it works.
So in that regard it actually also is in a certain form a placebo.
And a placebo is not nothing, placebo's work.
They don't work for what we think they work, but they have a, they work
based on belief and expectation and intent and actually the whole ritual.
So these were massive placebo's or interesting ways to
trigger the healing response and that pilgrimage is essential.
And that's also what I think that when we do it
ourselves, that we can best mimic a certain pilgrimage.
So if you have a question that is really relevant to you, don't
think well I'm just going to write it down and get an answer.
Say to the dream, hey on Saturday, two days from now,
I would love to get an answer to what is going on in my
stomach or how can I be a more loving person or I feel
so insecure, what can I, how can I better deal with it.
And then talk to the dream, prepare for it, he have special
food, put it all in in in in kind of a form of a pilgrimage.
And I did that as well. And so I walked in the
footsteps of these people, visited the place, felt the
beauty of the place and try to get as close as
possible to what these people might have experienced.
And it was very, very healing to be in a tradition that is
in the same way as I and had lived thousands of years ago.
And did you have a powerful dream when you were there?
The interesting thing is I had a very ordinary
dream and I first was a bit disappointed.
And then actually, because I thought, oh now I'm here, I get
a special revelation, this is great, and it was very ordinary.
But when I thought more about it, it was actually very astute
and was just what I needed to hear and was very practical.
So it brought me back to a very practical way of
being in the world, it was just the right thing.
So sometimes our own mind and thinking what shall I do is
actually an hindrance in interpreting or working with the dream.
I've seen that more often, people are, this dream either
doesn't mean anything or it's too simple or whatever.
And it's very often now, give it some time, let it simmer.
If we really work from the perspective that we're visiting this
wise old counselor or man or woman or phenomenon that really has
lived for millions of years and knows about our life and about
life in general and it gives us an answer, let's take it serious.
Absolutely.
You have studied many different traditions and cultures
that have worked with dreams for thousands of years.
What have you distilled from all of those different practices?
What I've noticed is that there are maybe two big ways of being with the dream.
One is the question that we all know, what does this mean? What does this dream mean?
And that leads to a form of interpretation.
The other is a far more who did I encounter in the dream?
Who is visiting?
How do I build a relationship with this dream being, this dream
allocator, this dream burglar, this dream figure, even the dream car?
Taking the beings in the dream world as real that
we can have relationships with and then doing
a little ritual for them, making a drawing,
talking to them, trying to communicate to them.
And you see that that kind of way of being with the dream is far more prevalent in
any shamanic tradition around the world and in also the deep spiritual traditions.
And that that interpretive way seems to be a little bit more a Western
way that is now dominant and also had its place throughout history.
But those are two big ways of being with the dream.
And I really put a lot of my own work in how do you relate to these dream
beings and also how can you sense the energy that is present in the dream?
Because what you very often see, if I am depressed, I might find in
the dream a happy kept driver or the upbeat newspapers salesperson.
And then I can connect with that energy of the up beatness, feel my
own depression and almost like in an alchemical vessel, hold both
states by which these two states of consciousness can come together
and merge and then an inner alchemical transformation takes place.
And that is very powerful because it's very easy to say,
well, don't feel depressed or be feel more confident.
And it's like, yeah, I know I want to be more
confident with how, but connecting to a character
that already embodies that and you can feel it in your own body will help you do that.
Yeah, you describe in your book how you use that embodied method
when you were going through your own experience of depression.
Yeah, I was in a depressive phase in life and then I
reached out to this Jungian analyst and dream worker Robert
Bosnak that I had worked with and trained with for a long
time and experienced these different states of consciousness.
So I felt the depression in my legs and how it was
heavy and how the energy was flowing out of it.
And then there were in the dreams different states of consciousness that came in.
By working on that, my depressive face cracked open and changed and luckily
I started feeling energetic again because depression is very difficult.
And instead of cutting it out or meditating it, which in some cases
is important, but by meditating it or cutting it out, it just lingers.
And if you work it and break it open, it
transforms and there's often some value in it and
you'll do something and that way you can get out
of it as well and usually more substantially.
I would imagine there might be people
listening now who might be thinking, well, I
have dreams, I'm not really sure what they mean or how can I work with my dreams.
I love the question. And there's several answers
to that. But one way that I sometimes encourage
people to do when they start with dream work
is asking you the question, what is happening?
So write down your dream in the present tense
because that gives more immediacy to the dream
and you will better be able to be in touch with
all kinds of feelings you have in the dream.
There's a difference between, I saw an alligator versus I am seeing an alligator.
And by seeing the alligator, the alligator comes in the room and now at once I
can start experiencing all the feelings and states of consciousness in that dream.
And then asking the question, let's say I have a dream, I am
walking in the street, I see an alligator, I get scared and I run.
What is happening is I'm just walking around, I see something that is really
threatening to me and when I see something is really threatening to me, I'm gone.
Then the next question is, is this a pattern you recognize
in your day-to-day life? And most often the answer is yes.
And sometimes it's like, oh yeah, no, I know where this is from, this is my boss.
Well, it's not your boss, but it's your response to your, you experience your boss
as a threatening figure and you have an habitual pattern probably that you're gone.
Other people might, in their fear, kick the alligator. So they have a fight response.
So you learn about your own responses and then you can work it further.
But that's a great way for people. So instead
of asking what does this mean, ask the
question, what is happening or another great
question that people can ask is, who is visiting?
Oh, alligator is visiting and then look at the specifics or burglar is visiting.
And of course, first impulse is go away, burglar. But then
it's like who is visiting and be a bit curious about it.
Because somehow your own psyche presents this to you and is probably with a purpose.
So why might burglar show up in your dream? Is it something that
you have in common or is that something in your environment?
And then you just maybe look at burglar, you
describe burglar, you know how burglar has
a hoodie on or not, looks angry or burglar
tries to get close to me to tell me something.
And at once the dream, you start noticing an
energetic shift in the dream by curiosity.
And the nice thing of that is you don't have to know much about dreaming,
you don't have to read all the symbols and fairy tales and mythic structures.
You can work with the dream and get some of its insight.
Because then at once maybe then you walk around with burglar throughout
the day and say, oh, burglar, what would you do in this situation?
And then you get some intuition. And then burglar says, well, I would
solve this way and you think, oh, that's actually really clever.
So that's a suggestion for people to play with.
And how would you describe what dream incubation is?
It's the very old technique where people ask the dream question
before they go to sleep in order to get an helpful response.
In the old days, it was very often around healing, but it can be done
for any question that is really relevant to your heart or to your soul.
And that's in a nutshell dream incubation.
You have devised simple steps for dream incubation. Are
you willing to give us some of those steps to help people?
Yes, absolutely, absolutely.
What I did is I looked at all these traditions throughout.
Well, first what I actually did was I think I noticed that you
could ask your dream a question and that it gave a response.
And I learned that a lot of people have figured it out spontaneously.
It seems to be kind of a spontaneous instinct that people already have.
And in the beginning, I just started asking the dream
all kinds of questions to figure out what does it say?
What does it answer? Because it doesn't answer
everything, but it doesn't answer specific things.
And I encourage people to play around with it.
I asked the tree in the yard if it had the
message. I asked the house. I asked the mountain.
If it knew the future, all kinds of things.
And so I first did that.
And then I studied all these traditions.
And I did that only after I played for it for a year and a half.
Because I wanted to build up my own ideas
before I read how it's being done in Buddhism.
And then just think that's how it's being done.
And then being stuck in a tradition that tells how it works.
And then I studied all these traditions.
And I noticed that you can distillate it to five steps.
And it's encompassing all with a certain sense of ritual.
So if you start from the beginning with a sense, hey, I'm on a pilgrimage.
I'm on a sacred journey to ask the larger
awareness that lifts outside and inside of us
for support and help on my life path.
For something that's relevant to my heart.
Then you can go to really step one is what is your question?
What would you want to know?
And I can go into the steps a little bit more.
But first, identify that you have a question.
Then step two is think really well about how you want to formulate a question.
Because I've learned that the dream is
responding to the way that you ask the question.
Just like if I ask you what time it is, you're going to tell me what time it is.
And if I ask you a different question, you'll give me a different answer.
So you want to ask the right question.
And also the right question will help you further.
Then step three is create a ritual.
And the ritual is some way of engaging with
your question and make it symbolically relevant.
Go to bed, meditate on it, sleep is step four and then five.
Write down the dream.
Because otherwise you forget it and engage with it, work with the dream.
So that's in a nutshell, the five steps.
And you can do that once.
You can also use it as a way over time to strengthen your relationship
with the larger awareness and be more connected in that way.
You suggest that people write their questions down.
And then in the morning, when they wake up before too
much time has passed to also write down their dream.
Yes.
And I don't know if you have ever had that experience that you wake up.
You think, oh, this is an interesting dream.
And then you get out of the shower or anything.
What was it?
I'm so convinced I would remember this.
Gone.
Yeah, exactly.
Yeah.
And that has to do with our short-term memory goes offline at night.
So actually, the wildest thing is our mind is still active while we're sleeping.
We're actually awake.
Our mind is awake.
We're just not aware.
And so it doesn't store.
And when we wake up, our memory function comes back online.
But it's not yet fully functioning.
So we need to repeat it a couple of times to ourselves.
The dream is gone.
And there's nothing to do with willpower, intelligence, dedication, write it down.
And me, after I don't know how many years, I still sometimes think, I'll know this.
And then I think how outcome that I think this.
But yeah.
Like capturing dew in the morning, I heard somebody say one time.
Yes.
You wait too long before the sun comes gone.
And it's the same with dreams.
But probably with any experience that we have with the other world,
one is that we know that time becomes relative.
And whether people have an out-of-body experience
and near-death experience are in the flow,
time becomes relative.
And that means we're connected to the other world.
So actually what is really important is that we figure
out where in our life does time become relative.
Because if time speeds up, it means we're connected with our deeper self.
That's usually what happens in the flow.
If time becomes really slow, we're disconnected from our self.
We're doing a task we don't like.
Or if people we don't like.
And it's just our own soul telling us, this is not a place to be.
And so when sometimes people say, I don't know
what my talent is or my gift or my purpose.
Look in those places in life where time becomes speeds up.
That's probably where your talent is hanging out.
Do you really think it is another world?
It's one way of imagining it.
You could think about it as you have waking
consciousness, our consciousness that we're in right now,
and beneath it is a different layer of consciousness.
And when we sleep, we'll descend into another state of consciousness.
Or when we hang out with our talent, these two starts merging.
But a dream is, if anyone goes back in their memory to a dream they had,
they will notice that they were in a location, in an environment, in a world.
They're somewhere, there is the car, there is grandfather,
and they have an interaction.
So the mind creates a world at night.
And so it's not a movie that you watch.
A movie is very two-dimensional.
It's not a letter you get from this resource X or your brain that's to you.
You're in a world where you interact.
And so just like we are in a world right now,
and when we wake up that world doesn't disappear,
that world continues to coexist.
And a day dreams are even reading a book.
What you notice is that if you're in a book, literally you're in the story,
and again you're in a world.
You're maybe walking in Vietnam in the jungle,
and you start seeing it if you're really in the story.
You start seeing the trees around you,
and you don't see the rest in the room,
but that world has re-emerged.
So it is always there and presents itself to us as a world.
So yeah, these worlds are co-existing.
It's like reading a book might be the imaginary world.
However, our dreams might be the imaginal.
Yeah.
It's more or less the same imaginative, imaginal world.
At night we call it dream.
During the day we call it a fantasy or a day dream.
And then people have different experiences of being connected to the other world.
When people have reported near-death experience,
they are in a certain world.
When people take psychedelics, they are in a certain imaginal world.
And so there are all these imaginal worlds.
And the world of dream is actually just one variation of the flow of life,
just as a fountain producing worlds.
We live in a world creating the soul,
or the life force's world creating,
and it does that constantly.
Even this world we're right now in,
is a world that actually takes place in our own psyche,
and it is our own psyche that creates the world we're in.
I see a different world than you see.
Yeah.
Just to get back to the steps for a moment,
when you talked about a ritual,
I like how you mentioned about writing down the question, focusing on it,
maybe even building up to it for a couple of days,
or thinking about it throughout the day, getting really focused,
making it simple so you're not trying to have five questions answered in one dream
because you can get a lot of information.
It can be confusing to kind of sift through what is answering what.
You also give an example in your book about how a few people,
one person for asking a question or getting guidance around love in their life,
I believe they drew a heart,
and I think they might have put it under their pillow,
or a person had a question around money,
and put a piece of money under their pillow when they slept at night
to help them focus on it when they slept and had their dream.
Yes.
So somehow the world of dream loves to be engaged in a playful,
imaginal, symbolic way.
It is both that we show to the dream.
It's like visiting this vice-counselor and being on time,
and listening, and just showing that we're interested.
And we do that also by creating something,
like this person with a love question, creates a heart,
with a question mark on it.
And anything that symbolically has a resonance with your question,
seems to enhance the likelihood of an response.
And this technique was also studied by Harvard,
and what they noticed is that the people that asked a question
that was relevant to their emotional life or to their health
had a high response rate.
If the question was too abstract,
it didn't trigger a good response.
If I want to know what did my neighbor have for dinner,
my soul thinks,
Machille, very uninteresting question.
But if I ask, how can I be more kind to myself
or can I communicate better?
Or what should I focus upon right now?
Or even questions like, you want to earn money?
Great, of course.
A good question.
But if you phrase it a little bit more generous,
like, how can I bring my services to the world
to the people that will benefit from it?
The dream seems to help even a little bit more in those cases.
If you just say, how can I have more money?
It might help.
If you make it a little bit more generous,
it's more likely to trigger a positive response.
And so that is why I also spent a little bit of time
thinking about your question.
And the ritual is so important because you show to the dream,
this is important to me.
You mentioned in your book a person
who is exploring which school to attend
and you described that they really didn't do their own homework
and the dream wants to support you,
but you also have to do your own due diligence
in regard to your own inquiry as well.
Yes.
So what I learned over time in my own life
and with the people I've worked with
is that the dream is not like the genie and allotin
that is just a wishful-filling spirit
that you can ask and it delivers.
It's more interested in really helping you.
So like a good coach,
it will not run for you the five-mile.
It runs you to run the five-mile so that you get your endurance.
And it also wants you to do your homework first.
So exhaust your own thinking
and when you've reached the point
that you don't know, really don't know,
then you go to the dream.
So this girl wanted to go to a school on psychology
and was very quickly,
well, dream which school shall I go to?
And then didn't get an answer.
So not getting an answer is also an answer.
Then the dream tells you I'm not helping you with this one.
And in this case it was well,
but start looking at which schools there are,
which you're interested in.
Maybe you can figure it out yourself.
And if you then still don't know,
then you go to the dream.
And that is important in this method.
Yeah.
I like that you picked that up.
Thank you.
It's probably not uncommon for you
that you hear people say,
I don't remember my dreams.
What advice can you give to those people?
Some people say,
I used to dream.
I never dream anymore.
Or I don't remember my dreams.
Research shows that we dream every night,
several hours actually.
And because of that short-term memory,
not functioning, we don't remember it.
What appears to be the number one way
to trigger dream recall is curiosity.
If you turn to the dream and say,
I've been listening to Emmy and Mahil today.
It sounds interesting.
I'm not sure, but I would love to have a dream tonight.
Then you show interest.
And then the second best thing to do
is get a pencil and paper next to your bed
because the dream disappears upon waking most of the time.
And then write down what in the morning write down,
even if it's a feeling or a thought.
And then within days,
if it's not the first night, second, third night,
you'll have a dream.
So dreams just respond to interest, curiosity,
and your ability to write them down.
That's in a nutshell,
the method for dream recall
and will work.
Yeah.
How is your dream life?
How often do you remember a dream?
I remember dreams pretty frequently.
Since reading your book and thank you,
I have found that I'm able to connect with dreams much better.
And they do seem to connect with the questions that I have.
And I am able to get information that is helpful in my life.
I love to hear that.
And I wonder, have you ever tested try this method before?
Have tried to get questions answered in dreams.
But I don't think I was able to focus as much.
I think that one of the key takeaways,
I mean, you do a really beautiful job of outlining steps,
but also a key takeaway is that focus
and really thinking about it.
And that's really what, you know,
research is shown for these kind of phenomena
and connecting with ourselves is that
intention and attention can produce results most of the time.
Yes.
And how great that you were able to ask questions
and get answers.
Yeah.
And I have a family member who is going through some health challenges
and I am helping oversee their care.
And it's a lot of responsibility.
It's one of the most challenging experiences I've ever had in my life.
I asked a dream what would help me with that.
And I shared a little bit with you about this
before our conversation here.
And it essentially seems that it was encouraging me
